contacts.name: Hosam Faysal
contacts.title: Acting Head of IFRC Country Delegation, Syria

field_reports.description:
Overview

Wildfires that first ignited on 30 June 2025 in the northeastern part of Latakia Governorate have evolved into a severe emergency, with conditions rapidly deteriorating due to environmental and security challenges. The initial outbreak was followed by significant fire expansion on 2–3 July, driven by high temperatures, strong eastern winds, and extremely dry vegetation. These conditions have severely hindered firefighting operations.

On 4 July, the Government of Syria (GoS) issued a formal request for international assistance, leading to the deployment of firefighting teams and aerial support from Turkey, Jordan, Lebanon, Iraq, and Qatar. Despite these efforts, a renewed and extreme flare-up occurred on 11 July, further aggravated by persistent strong winds, inaccessible terrain, and the presence of unexploded ordnance and landmines.

Additional wildfire outbreaks have been reported in Hama and Tartous Governorates, broadening the geographic scope of the crisis. These compounded challenges have necessitated sustained national and international coordination to contain the fires and address growing humanitarian needs.

Humanitarian Impact
Approximately 25,000 individuals have been affected by the wildfires across the impacted governorates, while the latest estimates indicate that over 50,000 people have been exposed.
At least 2,000 people have been evacuated from high-risk communities, including Sheikh Hassan, Al-Shajara, Beit Ayoush, Al-Mazra’a, and Saboura.
More than 127 locations across Latakia and Tartous Governorates have been affected to varying degrees, including damage to homes, farmland, public infrastructure, and essential services.
Over 15,000 hectares of agricultural land and forests have burned, causing widespread destruction of olive groves, seasonal crops, livestock, and beehives, further worsening food insecurity in rural areas already facing economic fragility.
Damage to electricity infrastructure and water networks has halted operations at several water pumping stations, resulting in water access disruptions in surrounding communities and increasing the risk of waterborne diseases and hygiene-related health issues.
The wildfires have also disrupted the tourism sector, eliminating a major seasonal income source for many households.
Firefighting efforts have faced major challenges due to rugged terrain, strong winds, and limited resources, highlighting the urgent need to strengthen national firefighting and rapid response capacities.
Communities are experiencing mass displacement, loss of property, and disruption of livelihoods, placing immense pressure on already fragile coping capacities, as new groups of affected families are being added to those already exhausted.
Under these circumstances, new categories of vulnerable families are emerging—families that were not previously among those receiving humanitarian support, necessitating an expansion of humanitarian response efforts and ongoing updates to field assessments.

contacts.name: Hosam Faysal
contacts.title: Acting Head of IFRC Country Delegation

field_reports.description:
A series of wildfires began on 30 June 2025 and were formally announced by the government on 3 July, spreading across multiple villages in rural northeastern Latakia, including Al-Rihaniyah, Shalaf, Zanzouf, Ghassaniyeh, Al-Atirah, and Beit Al-Qusayr, fueled by hot eastern winds, dry vegetation, and difficult terrain. These fires have quickly overwhelmed already exhausted local firefighting capacity and led to significant displacement and material loss.

Context: Recurrent Crises in Latakia

  • Latakia, typically seen as one of Syria’s more stable regions, has faced a series of compounded crises over the years. In addition to hosting large numbers of displaced people from other governorates, the area has experienced:
  • March 2025 Security Incidents: In March 2025, localized unrest was reported in parts of Latakia and Tartous governorates, linked to rising community-level tensions.
  • Recurring wildfires, notably in early  2020, 2022, 2023, and 2024, have damaged forests and agricultural lands critical for local livelihoods.
  • Ongoing economic hardship linked to the national crisis continues to limit fuel availability and weaken public services such as firefighting, while liquidity constraints are also affecting the ability of SARC to sustain and scale up their response.

·         These overlapping hazards have significantly eroded community resilience and the ability of local systems to respond to new emergencies.

Impact of the Current Fires

  • Around  5,000 people have been directly and indirectly affected.
  • At least 1120 individuals have been moved, particularly from Beit Ayoush, Al-Mazra’a, and Saboura, where homes were directly threatened.
  • Fires have destroyed crops, olive groves, and livestock, notably in Beit Ayman, Al-Iman, and Kastal Maaf, deepening food insecurity for already vulnerable communities.
  • The blaze has spread toward Qandil Valley and Jabal Al-Basit, increasing the risk to surrounding villages.

·         Security conditions in parts of Latakia and surrounding highland and border areas remain complex. Between May and June 2025, increased aerial activity. The presence of unexploded ordnance and remnants of past hostilities, particularly in former frontlines and border villages, continues to pose risks to both residents and humanitarian personnel. The security incidents of 8 December and March 2025 also underline the sensitivity of the area and the need for careful access coordination. While SARC teams are actively responding, movement into remote fire-affected areas requires ongoing coordination with local authorities due to access constraints, fuel shortages.

results.summary:
A series of wildfires began on 30 June 2025 and were formally announced by the government on 3 July, spreading across multiple villages in rural northeastern Latakia, including Al-Rihaniyah, Shalaf, Zanzouf, Ghassaniyeh, Al-Atirah, and Beit Al-Qusayr, fueled by hot eastern winds, dry vegetation, and difficult terrain. These fires have quickly overwhelmed already exhausted local firefighting capacity and led to significant displacement and material loss.

Context: Recurrent Crises in Latakia

  • Latakia, typically seen as one of Syria’s more stable regions, has faced a series of compounded crises over the years. In addition to hosting large numbers of displaced people from other governorates, the area has experienced:
  • March 2025 Security Incidents: In March 2025, localized unrest was reported in parts of Latakia and Tartous governorates, linked to rising community-level tensions.
  • Recurring wildfires, notably in early  2020, 2022, 2023, and 2024, have damaged forests and agricultural lands critical for local livelihoods.
  • Ongoing economic hardship linked to the national crisis continues to limit fuel availability and weaken public services such as firefighting, while liquidity constraints are also affecting the ability of SARC to sustain and scale up their response.

·         These overlapping hazards have significantly eroded community resilience and the ability of local systems to respond to new emergencies.

Impact of the Current Fires

  • Around  7500 people have been directly and indirectly affected.
  • At least 1120 individuals have been moved, particularly from Beit Ayoush, Al-Mazra’a, and Saboura, where homes were directly threatened.
  • Fires have destroyed crops, olive groves, and livestock, notably in Beit Ayman, Al-Iman, and Kastal Maaf, deepening food insecurity for already vulnerable communities.
  • The blaze has spread toward Qandil Valley and Jabal Al-Basit, increasing the risk to surrounding villages.
  • Essential services, including water supply, have been disrupted. According to the Latakia Water Establishment, power cuts caused by the fires have halted water pumping operations in key stations (e.g., Al-Zour, Ballouan, Al-Namleh, and Al-Basit junction). This has impacted water access in dozens of villages, including Zour Sharifa, Joubet Sharifa, Brashitou, Ballouan, Zghrin, Al-Namleh, Al-Duha, and others, raising public health and hygiene concerns amid ongoing displacement.

·         Security conditions in parts of Latakia and surrounding highland and border areas remain complex. Between May and June 2025, increased aerial activity. The presence of unexploded ordnance and remnants of past hostilities, particularly in former frontlines and border villages, continues to pose risks to both residents and humanitarian personnel. The security incidents of 8 December and March 2025 also underline the sensitivity of the area and the need for careful access coordination. While SARC teams are actively responding, movement into remote fire-affected areas requires ongoing coordination with local authorities due to access constraints, fuel shortages.
results.name: SYR: Fire - 07-2025 - Fire

contacts.name: Hosam FAYSAL
contacts.title: Acting Head of IFRC Country Delegation, Syria

field_reports.description:
The escalating hostilities that have recently occurred in the northern governorates of Syria, specifically Aleppo, Idlib, and Hama, have led to the displacement of approximately 500,000 individuals inside and outside these governorates in search of safety and protection. This increase in violence has exacerbated the vulnerabilities of communities already struggling with the prolonged crisis, earthquake repercussions, economic difficulties, the recent influx of displacement from Lebanon, and direct environmental pressures in densely populated areas.

All governorates, especially those directly affected, are currently facing a severe shortage of humanitarian assistance and basic necessities due to the protracted crisis, which is considered one of the longest and most complex in the world. Already weakened communities in these areas are now grappling with the aftermath of a devastating earthquake that struck the region in 2023, further worsening their already dire situation. Additionally, neighboring areas previously inundated by waves of displacement are now under additional strain on their resources and services. The onset of winter has exacerbated vulnerabilities, leaving families without adequate shelter, heating, or essential non-food items.

Moreover, the recent displacement has disproportionately affected women, children, and the elderly, increasing their needs compared to other demographics and exposing them to additional risks. Despite efforts to alleviate the crisis, maintaining resilience in the most vulnerable families becomes increasingly challenging within the fragile context of limited and often absent resources.

In areas like Aleppo and Idlib, the gap between life-saving basic needs and resources accessible to the affected populations widens due to conflict and the lack of safe access to service providers and supplies, despite facilitation by many stakeholders and interest parties.

The military operations are not over as of the drafting of this report and further escalation could be expected in the coming days. The area of conflict has widened through Aleppo and rural Aleppo, Eastern and southern Idleb, and northern Hama. The population living in the currently affected areas is estimated at 3,170,000 people. Isolated incidents have also been recorded in other governorates which would increase the risk of further displacement within these governorates or in-between different governorates. As information starts to trickle in, there will be more clarity on numbers and specific needs It is to be noted that the situation remains extremely fluid.

Immediate response efforts focus on the following:

- Establishing safe evacuation corridors and providing life-saving assistance, including food and NFIs

- Ensuring a safe supply of water sources and coordinating with sector workers for safe passage

- Providing emergency healthcare and medical aid,

- Supplying hospitals with essential materials and providing safe passage for medical supplies across conflict lines

- Family reunification services and dead body management

- Enhancing coordination between local and international actors to address aid gaps and ensure fair distribution

-Sanitation and Waste management

-  Enhanced targeting of most vulnerable populations, and expansion of services to include Mental Health and Psychosocial Support (MHPSS), protection services

results.name: SYR: Complex Emergency - 11-2024 -

appeals.sector: Middle East and North Africa Regional Office

field_reports.description:
Since October 7, 2023, the humanitarian situation in the Gaza Strip has been dire following the recent escalation of violence. According to the United Nations, Over 1 million people have been displaced from their homes in the Gaza Strip, and thousands of homes and businesses have been destroyed. The conflict has also caused widespread damage to infrastructure, including hospitals, schools, and water and electricity systems. 


In addition to the destruction of property, the conflict has also had a devastating impact on people's lives. The total statistics according to the Palestinian Ministry of Health show that Gaza reported cases since the beginning of the events 4,137 deaths, in addition to more than 13,162 injuries. Most of the injuries are caused by shrapnel and gunshot wounds. The conflict has also caused widespread trauma and psychological distress. 

The total cases dealt with by PRCS ambulance teams since the beginning of the events are (6007) cases, including 1464 fatalities and 4543 injuries.

The health system in the Gaza Strip is struggling to cope with the influx of casualties. Hospitals are overcrowded, and medical supplies are running low. The power grid is also damaged, making it difficult to operate hospitals and other essential services. Since the start of the escalation of hostilities, four schools and eight healthcare facilities in Gaza have sustained damage.

Since the closure of the border, 105 Palestinians have been stuck on the Egyptian side of the border. They are suffering from a lack of food, medication, and shelter.

The already dire humanitarian context inside Gaza is deteriorating further, resulting in large-scale displacement inside Gaza and potentially across the Rafah border into Egypt.
Drawing from past escalation events and historical context, Egypt has played a crucial role in facilitating medical treatment for critically injured individuals evacuated to its hospitals, hosting displaced populations, and acting as a channel for humanitarian aid destined for the Gaza Strip, either originating from Egypt or dispatched internationally through it. The Egyptian Red Crescent is the only organization with access to North Sinai and already holds operations and projects in the area.

Today on the 21st of October 2023, a total of 20 ERCS trucks crossed the Rafah borders carrying aid that is based on the coordinated needs of PRCS, which included

  • Six trucks carrying: Medicine
  • Seven trucks: Medical Consumbles
  • Five trucks: Food Items.
  • Two trucks: Water

The trucks make their way into Gaza through the PRCS, in coordination with authorities on both sides to ensure the safe delivery of items.

Since 7 October 2023, The humanitarian situation in the Gaza Strip is dire following the recent escalation of violence. According to the United Nations Over 187,518 people have been displaced from their homes in the Gaza Strip, and thousands of homes and businesses have been destroyed. The conflict has also caused widespread damage to infrastructure, including hospitals, schools, and water and electricity systems. About 3,000 Palestinians in Gaza are still displaced following previous escalations.(1)

In addition to the destruction of property, the conflict has also had a devastating impact on people's lives. The total statistics according to the Palestinian Ministry of Health that Gaza reported cases since the beginning of the events (1100) Deaths, including (270) children and (240) women, in addition to more than (5339) injuries. The majority of the injuries are caused by shrapnel and gunshot wounds. The conflict has also caused widespread trauma and psychological distress. (2)

The total cases dealt with by PRCS ambulance teams since the beginning of the events are (2492) cases, including
(478) fatalities and (2014) injuries.

The displacement of a very large number of citizens from the border areas in the governorates to the heart of the cities
was recorded in shelter centers or with host families, as the United Nations Relief and Works Agency for Refugees
(UNRWA) announced that its centers received more than 200,000 displaced people in its shelter centers, while official sources announced The number of displaced people has increased to more than 330,000 in different regions.

The health system in the Gaza Strip is struggling to cope with the influx of casualties. Hospitals are overcrowded and medical supplies are running low. The power grid is also damaged, making it difficult to operate hospitals and other essential services. Since the start of the escalation of hostilities, four schools and eight healthcare facilities in Gaza have sustained damage.

Since the closure of the border, 37 Palestinians have been stuck on the Egyptian side of the border. They are suffering from a lack of food, medication, and shelter.
The already dire humanitarian context inside Gaza is deteriorating further resulting in large-scale displacement inside Gaza and potentially across the Rafah border into Egypt.

It is Israel will keep all entry and exit points to Gaza, closed for the coming months and as will not allow the opening of a humanitarian corridor for emergency goods and into Gaza. 

Drawing from past escalation events and historical context, Egypt has played a crucial role in facilitating medical treatment for critically injured individuals evacuated to its hospitals, hosting displaced populations, and acting as a channel for humanitarian aid destined for the Gaza Strip, either originating from Egypt or dispatched internationally through it. The Egyptian Red Crescent is the only organization with access to North Sinai and already holds operations and projects in the area.

In the wake of a notable escalation in conflict within Palestine and the increasing tensions at the Lebanese Southern borders, a disturbing scenario reminiscent of the 2006 war between Lebanon and Israel begins to unfold. This scenario depicts an armed conflict primarily involving Hezbollah and Israel. The conflict manifests as a series of intense air raids and attacks, strategically targeting not only the southern regions of Lebanon but also the densely populated southern suburbs of Beirut, the agriculturally rich north of Bekaa, and the border areas, leaving a trail of destruction in its wake. In addition to the external dangers, internal political/security instability poses an imminent risk to inter/intra-communal groups. Scenario Assumptions: • Hezbollah-Israel Armed Conflict • Air Raids and Rocket Attacks • Internal Displacement • Lebanese Armed Forces (LAF) involvement • Blockades and Naval Operations • Risks to Syrian Refugees • Foreign Involvement

results.summary:
Since 7 October 2023, hostilities have significantly escalated across the Gaza Strip and the West Bank, leading to a severe humanitarian crisis in the occupied Palestinian territories (oPt). The situation continues to deteriorate rapidly, with increasing casualties, damaged infrastructure, restricted access, and mass internal displacement.

As of 15 September 2024, more than 41,252 Palestinians have been killed in Gaza [OCHA]. Over 1.9 million people in Gaza are estimated to be internally displaced [OCHA]. The Gaza Strip has been under an electricity blackout since 11 October 2023, and a severe fuel shortage has led to the closure of most hospitals, particularly in the north. This has increased the pressure on remaining medical facilities and resulted in a rise in medical evacuations to neighboring countries.

Food and water supplies in Gaza are critically low, with only a fraction of the needed aid arriving through the borders. Humanitarian access remains highly restricted, with significant challenges including fuel shortages, communication shutdowns, and stringent restrictions. Safe passage for humanitarian aid remains key to deliver life-saving supplies. [OCHA]

In the West Bank, as of 10 September 2024, at least 705 Palestinians have been killed and over 5,700 injured since 7 October 2023 [OCHA]. The region has seen a significant increase in violence: between 7 October 2023 and 12 August 2024, OCHA recorded around 1,250 attacks by Israeli settlers against Palestinians, leading to fatalities, injuries, and property damage. 

The humanitarian situation is further compounded by movement restrictions. This has disrupted access to essential services, including healthcare, which has faced over 500 attacks since October 2023. Displacement is also a major issue with 88 thousands IDPs according to UN reports.

Meanwhile, increased conflicts along the southern borders of Lebanon in recent months, with a spike in September 2024, have led to a sharp increase in internal displacement, with different reports indicating the number of IDPs as anywhere between 200,000 upwards to the hundreds of thousands. As of 27 September 2024, at least 1640 civilians have been killed, and 8408 injured. [MoPH]. Lebanon is experiencing a multi-layered crisis, exacerbated by the ongoing conflict. The country is dealing with a protracted political, financial, and socio-economic crisis, which has severely impacted the availability and affordability of basic services such as healthcare, education, and clean water.

The International Federation of Red Cross and Red Crescent Societies (IFRC) and its National Societies have been providing critical assistance, including medical care, food, water, and shelter. Despite these efforts, the scale of the crisis requires more resources and support to meet the growing needs.
results.name: Middle East Crisis | MENA

field_reports.summary: SYR: Fire - 2023-07 - Syria Wild Fires July 2023
field_reports.description:
Multiple Fires have broken out around the coastal and central areas and in Syria. Possible reasons behind these fires differ, including the warm eastern winds that are active during this time of the year in Syria, in addition during the summer there are many dry herbs that burn quickly and the moisture content of the trees is less What is possible during periods of the year, in addition to the high temperature during this period. It is not excluded that there are fires caused by human errors and the intensity of the fires increased from 15 July 2023, which included the  Homs governorate, Hama governorate, and  Lattakia governorate. Most of the fires were in rugged mountainous remote areas. The intensity and size of bushfires in some areas have led to the creation of their own weather systems, generating pyro cumulonimbus clouds, trapping heat, and generating strong wind, in turn sparking further fires. High winds have also helped the bushfires to spread, with some fires jumping over highways and roads. These fires led to material and environmental damage, as a few homes of a number of residents were torched, in addition to burning agricultural crops on which they depend as a main source of livelihood, in addition to burning a large part of the vegetation, forests, and natural reserves.

In addition, there are many warnings by the government, which are as follows:

High levels of fire risk are expected to continue affecting most forest sites in the governorates of Hama and Homs and the eastern parts of the governorates of Lattakia and Tartous during Friday 21 and Saturday 22 July 2023, with the participation of the impact of medium levels on forest sites close to the coastal strip. Normal conditions of heat and dryness continue to support high levels of fire hazard.

So far the directly affected families numbers are limited comparing with previous years, all  the hazards mentioned above are raising the expectations for more fires during the coming days, the indirect effect of this fires will increase our challenges against alleviate the sufferance of the families in the affected areas and protect the remaining resilience in these communities.

field_reports.description:
After more than ten years of conflict in Syria, access to water has become one of the most prominent humanitarian challenges, which is exacerbated by climate change. According to severity scale updated in June 2023, all of Al-Sweida’s districts are ranked at levels 3 to 5, meaning they are facing a major, severe, or critical problem in water needs. The Al-Sweida governorate faced during this period a sharp decline in the water availability, the causes of which appear to be the intertwining of many factors: Loss of the main source of drinking water since 2012 the increase of the population between 2010 and 2022, increasing the demand on water and pressure on resources, and the decrease in the maintenance and technical level of logistical operating equipment. The level of the surface dams has decreased to a hazardous level and with some close to being completely dry.

 

The main reasons relate to the fact that rainfall has decreased significantly in recent years, additionally climate change has led to a lack of snowfall in large quantities which is the main source of dam water collection. Other reasons involve low electrical voltage because of the huge destruction of the infrastructures related to electrical supplies and lack of fuel and spare parts, which is the main cause of the malfunction of the pumps,
 in addition to the technical and logistical problems of the Water Corporation in Al-Sweida Governorate, which led to a large number of wells being out of service (around 80%). Moreover, Land irrigation, illegal extraction, and vandalism also helped exacerbate the water crisis in the governorate, with no capacity to replace or maintain due to the continue crises and sanctions among other clear effects of the climate changes and global warming. In June of 2023, reports confirmed through official channels that the water crisis in Al-Sweida governorate is severe, and that within two months, water will run out in surface dams. Not solving the problem of pumps in the wells will lead to the exit of more wells from the service, and thus exacerbate the water crisis that leads to a severe humanitarian disaster affecting 650,000 people. This will increase challenges and decrease resilience in these communities.

results.name: SYR: Drought - 2023-05 - Syria Droughts 2023

contacts.name: Abdul Basit Khan SWATI
contacts.title: Disaster Risk Management Delegate in iraq

field_reports.summary: SYR: هزة أرضية - 2023-02 - IRQ:IRCS-RESPONSE TO EARTHQUAKE IN  SYRIA #2 (2023-02-23)
field_reports.description: After the earthquake occurred on 6/2/2023 in the Syrian Arab Republic, the cities that were in contact with the seismic line were exposed to human and material losses, and because Syria suffers from economic crises for long periods, the damage resulting from the earthquake became clear, as there is no fuel, food, or shelter, and the Syrian people suffer. From the lack of technical equipment to the rescue.

An earthquake of 7.7 magnitudes was recorded at 04:17 , Center: Turkish Syrian border - Ghazi Entab, and  An  6.3 magnitudes was recorded at the same time (reaction) in Syria and affected all governorates in Syria, especially (Aleppo, Lattakia, Hama, Idleb, and Tartous)  on February 6th 2023 and continued within 7 aftershocks decreased gradually, till 1130 of 6th Feb the building still collapsing in Aleppo and Lattakia.

The Syrian government has reported till 09:00 am, 237 people lost their lives, and 700 people were injured in all affected provinces. The Syrian government is currently fulfilling the process of damage detection with all Partners and stockholders, The Goverment of Syria called for an urgent meetings with all partners and established a national committe to manage this disaster.

the communities are very Hash and sverely affected, suffering already due to economy situation and sanctions and the long term crises, pibplic services and institioution are in huge lack in tools - fuel - vehicles ...etc (Civil Defence - Figher fighting ... etc).

Numbers of Casuality is increasing and many are still stuck under the collapsed buildings.

results.summary:
On 6 February at 4:17 am, a 7.8 degrees magnitude earthquake struck southern Turkey near Syria’s northern border. The US Geological Survey said the earthquake was centered about 33 km (20 miles) from Gaziantep, a major city and provincial capital. Tremors were felt as far away as Lebanon, Greece, Palestine, and the island of Cyprus. Another big earthquake was felt on the same day at around 1:24 pm local time, largely in the same affected areas. Aftershocks will continue to shake the area as fault lines adjust to such a huge initial tremor. There’s even a risk—albeit a small one—of an aftershock bigger than the original quake.

SARC’s analysis currently stated that Aleppo, Latakia, Hama, and Tartous are the governorates affected the most by the earthquake, and assessments in neighboring governorates are underway. According to the Syrian MoH’s recent figures, as of 28 February, the number of casualties stood at 1,414 deaths and 2,357 injured in affected governorates. The numbers are expected to increase in the coming days. Major infrastructure damage is being witnessed and raising concerns in Aleppo, Latakia, Hama and Tartous Governorates (in the major cities and in the countryside). The extent of damage is being continuously assessed due to the wide range of affected areas by the earthquake.

The earthquake hit amid a very harsh winter with some areas in the northern part of the country hitting sub-zero temperatures, at a time when people are facing huge electricity, fuel, and water shortages.

The Syrian crisis is today even more critical than ever, with a multitude of challenges that make it one of the world’s most complex humanitarian emergencies. A decade of protracted crisis and economic collapse has left more than 15.3 million people in need of some form of humanitarian assistance

SARC also suffered some losses and damage to their infrastructure. A warehouse in Latakia has completely collapsed and another branch building was affected. Another Primary Health Care Centre (PHC) in Hama was also affected and needed to be immediately evacuated. Some Mobile Health Units were unable to move.
results.name: Syria: Earthquake - 2023-02

contacts.name: Randa Bani Oudeh
contacts.title: Head of Projects and Planning dept - PRCS HQ

field_reports.summary: SYR: Earthquake - 2023-02 - Syria EQ 2023, PRCS-Syria Response
field_reports.description:
In the aftermath of Feb-6 earthquake in Syria affected Palestinian Refugee camps having a total population of 438000. PRCS Syria Branch responded to the EQ. initial assessment report indicate 15000 Palestinian Refugees were impacted by the EQ.

PRCS Syria Branch Provided first aid and other emergency support and is preparing to expand its operation support to reach all affected in the camps. 

PRCS Branch in Syria, is mandated to support the Palestinian refugee camps in Syria.

field_reports.description:
On 20th January 2022, an attack by ISS’s on Sina ’a prison in Al-Hasakah city resulted in rapidly escalating hostilities with gunfire and explosions reported from the area. Civilian casualties were reported and up to 75,000 people (15,000 families) were forced to move out from the neighborhoods or between houses where the main hostilities and fighting took place.
The pre-crisis conditions in the affected neighborhoods and the host communities were already critical with low resilience among the population to withstand any additional chock. 
Also, the Turkish invasion in many points (north of Hasakah + Ein Essa in Raqqa) increased the displacement towards an already exhausted community.

Since January 2021, Syria has witnessed unprecedented low water levels of the Euphrates River in addition to the seasonal erratic rainfall during 2020-2021, resulting harmful effect on all sectors (livelihood – livestock – drinking water – electricity generating – health ..etc)  in Syria especially in Aleppo, Deir-ez-Zor, Al-Hasakeh and Ar-Raqqa governorates. 
The Syrian Minister of Agriculture stated that ‘this year is the most dangerous in terms of drought in Syria since 1953’ . The combined effect from the reduced water levels in the Euphrates river and drought conditions have impacted the food and nutrition security of households dependent of agriculture in Ar-Raqqa and Deir-ez-Zor. Suffering 10 years of different effects due to Syrian crises (Covid-19, Economy crises ..etc) damaged the resilience of these communities and reduced their coping ability  to fit with such a situation.

Multiple Fires have broken out around the coastal areas in Syria. Possible reasons behind these fires differ, including the warm eastern winds that are active during this time of the year in Syria, in addition at the end of the summer there are many dry herbs that burn quickly and the moisture content of the trees is less What is possible during periods of the year, in addition to the high temperature during this period, and the fire may be transmitted through farmers burning crop residues and losing control of the fire. It is not excluded that there are fires caused by human errors and the intensity of the fires increased from 8 October 2020, which included the western rural Homs governorate, the eastern rural Tartous and the northern rural Lattakia. Most of the fires were in rugged mountainous remote areas. The intensity and size of bushfires in some areas has led to the creation of their own weather systems, generating pyro cumulonimbus clouds, trapping heat and generating strong wind and lightning strikes, in turn sparking further fires. High winds have also helped the bushfires to spread, with some fires jumping over highways and roads.
These fires led to material and environmental damage, as the homes of a number of residents were torched, in addition to burning agricultural crops on which they depend as a main source of livelihood, in addition to burning a large part of the vegetation, forests and natural reserves.
